results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 17. Europe: State and Power
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode examines the period of European history covering 1453 - 1700. At this time, Europe was no longer threatened by invading Turkey, and in the 16th and 17th century, North Western Europe became the dominant region. The 16th century brought change, evolution and expansion to agriculture, trade, painting, military, religion and science. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 19. Asia
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
Asian history, over the period 1600 - 1800, is examined in this episode, focusing on the countries of Japan, China and India. European influence was always at Asia’s door, but the final dominance from Europe did not come until 1800 - 1950. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.creator_credit_for_label: John Selwyn Gilbert, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest and Network Television

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 08. Islam
results.creator_credit: David Wright, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode looks at the development of Islam over the period AD 600 - 1200. In the 6th century, a Prophet called Mohamed was born in Mecca and later travelled to Medina where he established the first Muslim state and built the first mosque. By the 9th century, Muslims had established a house of science in Baghdad, and during the 10th, 11th and 12th centuries Islamic art and culture evolved. There are now over 600 million Muslims, accounting for 1/7 of the total population of the world. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 02. The Agricultural Revolution
results.creator_credit: Taylor Downing, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
The first agricultural Revolution (8,000 BC - 5,000 BC) began with the change in climatic conditions. Man began to cultivate the land rather than hunt and fish. Wheat, barley, maize and potato, once growing wild, were cultivated, and animals were domesticated so that man became tied to the land and began leading a more sedentary life. In time, village life began to exist and the birth of civilisation had begun. Based on The Times atlas of world history.
results.title_for_label: The World: A Television History. Ep. 02. The Agricultural Revolution
results.creator_credit_for_label: Taylor Downing, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 22. The Making of the United States of America
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 22 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode covers the evolution of the United States of America, over the period 1776 - 1890, from its struggle for independence through to the Civil War, and the abolishment of slavery. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

description_for_label:
Episode number 22 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode covers the evolution of the United States of America, over the period 1776 - 1890, from its struggle for independence through to the Civil War, and the abolishment of slavery. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 11. The Expansion of Europe
results.creator_credit: David Wright, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode covers a period of history from 1250-1500 that resulted in dramatic changes in Europe. Major conflicts continued as different countries struggled for power, and, although it was a time of great exploration and development, it was also a time of great disaster, with overpopulation, famine and plague sweeping across the continent. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 03. The Birth of Civilisation
results.creator_credit: Taylor Downing, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
The birth of civilisation (6,000 BC - 2,000 BC) was first recognised in Mesopotamia, Egypt, India and China. These four different civilisations were distinguishable from other cultures by several special features: the rise of cities and urban centres, craftsmanship, writing, a calendar, and mathematical skills. Dams and irrigation, also a feature, were set up to cultivate vast, dry lands. These were great achievements but with civilisation came the end of democracy, and although it was a decisive turning point in the advance of civilisation, it was at great human cost. Based on The Times atlas of world history.
results.title_for_label: The World: A Television History. Ep. 03. The Birth of Civilisation

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 12. China in Transition
results.creator_credit: David Wright, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode examines Chinese history over the period 581 - 1279. This period included a time of rich development for Chinese civilisation, and this program examines the influence of Chinese Buddhism on the Sui and Tang people. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Barton, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest and Network Television
results.brief_description: A series of 26 videos presenting a history of humankind from its origins to the shaping of the modern world. The series looks at significant developments and great historical achievements in culture, science, technology, war, society, religion and all aspects of man’s progress. Based on the Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 24. The End of the Old Order
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 24 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode examines the end of a period of European history, and the emergence of prosperity for the United States of America over the years 1914-1929. In 1914, European civilisation dominated the world, with Britain and France the major players, and Germany and Italy eager to replace them. This was the time of World War I, and by 1919, Europe was reshaped. The decade following, however, was one of immense prosperity for the United States of America. Based on The Times atlas of world history.
